questions.text:
Which of the following statement are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, repolarization, hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?
I. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage gated channels
II. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand gated channels
III. Depolarisation due to efflux of K+ through voltage gated channel
IV. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through ligand gated channel
V. Hyperpolarization dur to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Depolarization is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels.

When threshold stimulus is applied to the cell membrane at the point of stimulation the permeability of the membrane for Na+ ions increases. At the beginning the rise of permeability for Na+ is slow till it reaches the firing level.When the membrane depolarizes, the Na+ channels start opening up. The opening of the Na+ channels (m gates) depolarizes the membrane, further leading to the opening of a greater number of Na+ channels due to positive feedback mechanisms. As the concentration gradient and electrical gradient of this ion are directed inward, there occurs a rapid influx of Na+ ions into the cell.

Repolarization is due to efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels.

Repolarization occurs due to decrease in Na+ influx and increase in K+ efflux through the voltage-gated K+ channels which open later than Na+ channels but remain activated for prolonged periods.

Hyperpolarization is due to efflux of K+.

The slow efflux of K+ continues even after the resting membrane potential is reached resulting in a prolonged phase of hyperpolarization

questions.text:
True statement regarding skeletal muscle contraction are:
I. Extracellular Ca++ not important for contraction
II. Ca++ released from mitochondria
III. Ca++ releases from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
IV. Voltage gated Ca++ channel on sarcolemma has no role in EC coupling
V. Ca++ channel on sarcoplasmic reticulum has no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ca++ releases from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

One of the special features of the sarcoplasmic reticulum is that within its vesicular tubules is an excess of calcium ions in high concentration. Many of these calcium ions are released from each vesicle when an action potential occurs in the adjacent T tubule.

When the action potential reaches the tip of T-tubule, it activates the voltage-gated channels called DHP (dihydropyridine) receptors which are located in the T-tubule membrane. When the DHP is activated by the depolarization of T-tubules, it undergoes conformational changes which result in the opening of

RYR(Ryandonine receptor) channels which are calcium release channels. Due to opening of calcium release channels (RYR), calcium ions diffuse into the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils and causing skeletal muscle contraction.

Other options:

Option I: Extracellular calcium are necessary in muscle contraction. When there is decrease in extracellular calcium it leads to Hypocalcaemia which leads to opening of voltage-gated sodium channels and hence sodium influx resulting in sustained depolarization which leads to tetany.

Option II: Calcium ions are not released from mitochondria, they are released from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Option IV: The voltage-gated calcium channels which are present on T-tubule of sarcolemma activated by depolarizing stimulus is responsible for release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum hence voltage-gated calcium channels play role in excitation-contraction coupling.

Option V: Calcium channels on sarcoplasmic reticulum has very crucial role in excitation-contraction coupling.

questions.text:
Sequence after P wave?
a) a wave
b) 1st heart sound
c) Rapid filling of ventricles
d) t wave
questions.solution:
Sequence after p wave are:

'a' wave in JVP -> Rapid filling of ventricles (last Rapid filling phase) -> 1st Heart sound -> T wave

questions.text:
When a person changes posture from supine to standing
I. Increase in firing from baroreceptor
II. Decrease in firing from barorecptor
III. Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase
IV. Mesenteric vasoconstriction
V. Increases cardiac contractility
questions.solution:
The following changes occur when an individual moves from a supine position to a standing position:

  • When a person stands, a significant volume of blood pools in the lower extremities because of the high compliance of the veins. (Muscular activity would prevent this pooling.)
  • As a result of venous pooling and increased local venous pressure, P c in the legs increases and fluid is filtered into the interstitium. If net filtration of fluid exceeds the ability of the lymphatics to return it to the circulation, edema will occur.
  • Venous return decreases. As a result of the decrease in venous return, both stroke volume and cardiac output decrease (Frank-Starling relationship)
  • Arterial pressure decreases because of the reduction in cardiac output. If cerebral blood pressure becomes low enough, fainting may occur.
  • Compensatory mechanisms will attempt to increase blood pressure to normal. The carotid sinus baroreceptors respond to the decrease in arterial pressure by decreasing the firing rate of the carotid sinus nerves.
  • A coordinated response from the vasomotor center then increases sympathetic outflow to the heart and blood vessels and decreases parasympathetic outflow to the heart. As a result, heart rate, contractility, TPR, and venous return increase, and blood pressure increases toward normal.
  • Orthostatic hypotension (fainting or light-headedness on standing) may occur in individuals whose baroreceptor reflex mechanism is impaired (e.g., individuals treated with sympatholytic agents) or who are volume depleted.

questions.text: Macula densa formed by which part of nephron
questions.solution:
• Macula densa is made up of specialised cells located at the junction of thick ascending limb and Distal convoluted tubule (DCT).
  • They are modified epithelial cells present at the distal end of thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle (LOH) when it comes in contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles.
  • Macula densa acts as the sensor which monitors the change in ionic composition and rate of flow of the tubular fluid in the lumen of the tubule.
  • It provides an appropriate feedback signal to the renal corpuscle to change the rate of filtration so that it can meet the need of the kidney functions.

questions.text: This is a graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and O representing no filtration. Choose substances A, B, C respectively
questions.solution:
Substance A- polycationic

Substance B- neutral

Substance C- polyanionic

Order of filterability: polycationic> neutral> polyanionic  

(A>B>C)

  • Negatively charged large molecules are filtered less easily than Positively Charged Molecules of equal Molecular Size as the glomerular filtration is negatively charged.
  • Dextrans are polysaccharides that can be manufactured as neutral molecules or with negative or positive charges. Positively charged molecules are filtered much more readily than negatively charged molecules.
  • Neutral dextrans are also filtered more readily than negatively charged dextrans of equal molecular weight.

The basement membrane greatly hinders filtration of plasma proteins, partly because of strong negative electrical charges associated with the proteoglycans.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT concentration of all of the following decreases except
questions.solution:
• All of the following ions like bicarbonate, glucose and amino acids have decreased concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule(PCT) except chloride which has highest concentration.
  • In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids and other solutes. In the second half of the proximal tubule, little glucose and few amino acids remain to be reabsorbed. Instead, sodium is now reabsorbed, mainly with chloride ions.
  • The second half of the proximal tubule has a relatively high concentration of chloride (≈140 mEq/L) compared with the early proximal tubule (≈105 mEq/L) because when sodium is reabsorbed, it preferentially carries with it glucose, bicarbonate, and organic ions in the early proximal tubule, leaving behind a solution that has a higher concentration of chloride.
  • In the second half of the proximal tubule, the higher chloride concentration favours diffusion of this ion from the tubule lumen through the intercellular junctions into the renal interstitial fluid.

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis and chronic respiratory alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis

questions.text: Acid base monogram diagram is given below. Changes in PCO2 are shown by curve lines. Areas marked with A and D indicate which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: 'A' refers to chronic respiratory acidosis and 'D' refers to metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Rees- Ecker fluid is used as a diligent for which of the following
questions.solution: Rees-Ecker fluid is used as a diluent for RBC pipette for platelet count.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
i. FRC
ii. TLC
iii. VC
iv. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution: Functional residual capacity (FRC) and Total lung capacity (TLC) increases in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

questions.text: Deficiency of which clotting factor will not affect clotting invio?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of clotting factor 12 (Hageman factor or glass factor) will not affect clotting invivo.

Factor XII is activated to XIIa when it comes in contact with a negatively charged surface, foreign substances or rough surface. Its activation in the blood initiates an intrinsic pathway by activating factor XI (PTA) to XIa.

Factor XII deficiency is characterised by a markedly prolonged PTT(>100 seconds) with normal PT and bleeding time in patients with no personal or family history of excessive bleeding. Individuals with factor XII deficiency do not experience excessive bleeding, even after major surgical procedures or trauma.

Other options:

Option A: Factor V is Labile factor or proaccelerin . It is required for the formation of prothrombin activator and thus conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

Option B: Factor VII is Stable factor or Auto Prothrombin I or Proconvertin, SPCA. It is required for the Activation of factor X and thus formation of prothrombin activator in intrinsic Pathway.

Option C: Factor IX is Christmas factor, plasma thromboplastin component (PTC), Antihemophilic factor. It is essential for the formation of prothrombin activator in the intrinsic pathway. Its absence or deficiency causes haemophilia B which is an inherited disease and is similar to haemophilia A.

questions.text: Which type of amino acids are present in transmembranous part of a membrane receptor?
questions.solution:
Hydrophobic amino acids are present in the trans membranous part of a membrane receptor.

Most proteins in the plasma membrane are integral or transmembrane proteins having one or more relatively hydrophobic alpha-helical segments that traverse the lipid bilayer.

Proteins on the extracellular face of the membrane may be anchored by glycosylphosphatidylinositol(GPI) tails that are added post-translationally.

Multiple transmembrane-spanning proteins are often pores or molecular transporters while proteins that are superficially attached to the membrane via labile linkages are more likely to participate in signalling.

questions.text: Least frequency of basal electrical rhythm (BER) is seen in
questions.solution:
Least frequency of Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER) is seen in Stomach.

The slow waves which oscillate significantly are called basal electrical rhythm (BER) that occurs due to wide variation in the RMP of GI smooth muscles. The BER is present in all parts of GIT except in the oesophagus.

questions.text: Calculate respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50 kg body weight, CO2 exhaled 200 ml/min, and 02 consumed 250 ml/min
questions.solution:
Respiratory Quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilisation which can be used to estimate fat and carbohydrate utilisation.

The respiratory quotient for carbohydrates is 1.0.

The respiratory quotient for the fat is 0.70.

The respiratory quotient for the proteins is 0.80..

questions.text: In the diagram, a simple muscle twitch with a time trace below is recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency of this muscle. Time tracer is done with a 100 Hz tuning fork
questions.solution: Tetanizing frequency- Minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.
